Hi,

2009/5/20 Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...>:
>
> Another major piece of =
the puzzle is just=A0standard graph theory stuff, the
> layout of network n=
odes where both distance and weight are evolved.=A0 I've
> been using Graph=
 Drawing with Intelligent Placement (GRIP - see Pavel Gajier
> and Steven K=
obourov's work at U of Arizona).=A0 This describes the SA
> and=A0maximal i=
ndependent sets necessary to locate large numbers of nodes and
> describe t=
he graph thermodynamics.
> http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/gajer02grip.html

I =
don't really follow, is this some scheme to chose node coordinates
on the h=
yperneat substrate rather than using fixed points.


>
> The critical, fina=
l=A0piece of the puzzle is the application of Inverse Theory
> to Neuro Evo=
lution of Augmenting Topologies.=A0 This is=A0in answer to your
> question:=
 "What do you refine towards? e.g. when evolving a
> controller with no def=
ined 'correct' output?"

To me this definitely seems to be in the same ball=
park as RBMs, that
is, we can train a neural net based on how accurately it=
 models the
data from a stochastic point of view. We don't have to e.g. bac=
kprop
error values calculated against specific output targets, instead we
p=
ump noise into the high level feature nodes and monitor the frequency
with =
which certain output patterns occur. This gives us an objective
evaluation =
of the how well the domain in question is modelled. Now to
date I'm only aw=
are of modelling of simple imput-output relationships
such as handwriting r=
ecognition, but it should be possible to evaluate
(and indeed train) a mode=
l of a dynamic system (e.g. a robot arm that
picks up and moves an object).=
 The stochastic patterns are now spread
out over time and thus the weight u=
pdate rules are more complex, but
it's theoretically possible. Quite how th=
is fit in with HyperNEAT I'm
not sure, I suppose HyperNEAT can actually evo=
lve very complex
topologies if you take all connection weights below some v=
alue to be
not present, this trimmed down set of connections might then be
=
trained using the RBM-like update rules.



> The problem I have of describ=
ing the interrelationship of all the above with
> HyperNEAT is "it's all en=
tangled, and interrelated" - meaning it
> works=A0precisely like a TWEANN.=
=A0 I've been working with=A0NEAT devices for over
> eight years, Kohonen S=
OFM before that=A0- and I wish I could more precisely
> describe their beha=
vior in deterministic terms.=A0 I can't. I can describe
> them mathematical=
ly in probabilistic terms, but that isn't very satisfying
> to most folks.
=

Or most folks need to understand probabilistic models better, since
that's=
 where all the interesting/promising AI developments seem to be.
:)

Ken, I=
 feel like I'm on a different wavelength to you a lot of the
time but you s=
ure get the old brain cells working :)

Colin.
